CICERO To ATTICUS, GREETING.

Ι can quite believe what you explain at some Brundisium, length in your letter, that no advice of yours can July 5, mc. assist me: and certainly there is no consolation 47 which can relieve my sorrow. For none of my mis- fortunes has come upon me by fate—that would have been endurable—-but I have brought all on myself by my mistakes and my mental and bodily afflic- tionS‚ which I only wish my nearest and dearest had thought fit to remedy. So, as there is no hope of any advice from you or any consolation, I will not ask for them henceforth: only please do not cease from writing to me anything that may occur to you, when you have anyone to send it by, and so long as there is anyone to send it to3 which will not be long.
